{{Infobox protected area | name = Sarek National Park | alt_name = Sareks nationalpark | iucn_category = II | photo = Pierikpakte in Sarek.jpg | photo_width = 288 | photo_caption = The mountain [[Pierikpakte]] in the Äpar massif | location = [[Norrbotten County]], [[Sweden]] | nearest_city = | coords = {{coord|67|17|N|17|42|E|region:SE_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | area_km2 = 1970 | area_ref = <ref name="naturvårdsverket">{{cite web | title=Sarek National Park | url=http://www.naturvardsverket.se/Documents/publikationer/978-91-620-8478-3.pdf?pid=4159 | publisher=[[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)|Naturvårdsverket]] | accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> | established = 1909<ref name=swedishEPA>{{cite web|title=Sarek National Park|url=http://www.swedishepa.se/Enjoying-nature/Protected-areas/National-Parks/Sarek/|publisher=Swedish Environmental Agency|accessdate=20 July 2014}}</ref> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)|Naturvårdsverket]] | website = }} {{Swedish National Parks}} '''Sarek National Park''' ({{lang-sv|Sareks nationalpark}}) is a [[national park]] in [[Jokkmokk Municipality]], [[Lapland (Sweden)|Lapland]] in northern Sweden. Established in 1909–1910, the park is one of the oldest national parks in Europe. It is adjacent to two other national parks, namely [[Stora Sjöfallet National Park|Stora Sjöfallet]] and [[Padjelanta National Park|Padjelanta]]. The shape of Sarek National Park is roughly circular with an average diameter of about {{convert|50|km|mi|2|abbr=on}}.
The most noted features of the national park are six of Sweden's thirteen peaks over {{convert|2000|m|ft|abbr=on}} located within the park's boundaries. Among these is the second highest mountain in Sweden, [[Sarektjåkkå]], whilst the massif [[Áhkká]] is located just outside the park. The park has about 200 peaks over {{convert|1800|m|ft|abbr=on}}, 82 of which have names. Sarek is also the name of a geographical area which the national park is part of. The Sarek mountain district includes a total of eight peaks over {{convert|2000|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Due to the long trek, the mountains in the district are seldom climbed. There are approximately 100 glaciers in Sarek National Park.
Sarek is a popular area for hikers and mountaineers. Beginners in these disciplines are advised to accompany a guide since there are no marked trails or accommodations and only two bridges aside from those in the vicinity of its borders. The area is among those that receives the heaviest rainfall in Sweden, making hiking dependent on weather conditions. It is also intersected by [[Turbulence|turbulent]] streams that are hazardous to cross without proper training.
The [[river delta|delta]] of the [[Rapa River]] is considered one of Europe's most noted views and the summit of mount [[Skierfe]] offers an overlook of that ice-covered, [[Glacier|glacial]], trough valley.
The Pårte [[Research station|Scientific Station]] in Sarek (also known as the ''Pårte observatory'') was built in the early 1900s by Swedish [[Mineralogy|mineralogist]] and [[Geography|geographer]] [[Axel Hamberg]]. All the building material for the huts had to be carried to the site by [[Porter (carrier)|porters]].
== Names of locations == In Sarek National Park, as in the most of Sápmi, a large number of the locations have names originating from the [[Sami languages]].<ref name="Curry-Lindahl8">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=8}}</ref> These languages have several variations and their written forms have changed over time, which explains why some placenames do not always correspond with each other in different sources.<ref name=ortnamn>{{cite web|url=http://www.sprakradet.se/1717|publisher=Institut for språk och folkminnen|title=Samiska ortnamn|accessdate=27 October 2011|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015025601/http://www.sprakradet.se/1717|archivedate=15 October 2012|df=}}</ref>
The most common Sami names for locations or features in the park are ''tjåkkå'' or ''tjåkko'' (mountain), ''vagge'' (valley), ''jåkkå'' or ''jåkko'' (stream), ''lako'' (plateau) and ''ätno'' (river).<ref name="Curry-Lindahl131-133">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|pp=131–133}}</ref> An example of this is ''Rapaätno'', meaning [[Rapa River]]. These names are also the official Swedish names of the locations.
== Geography == [[File:Padjelanta Sarek Stora Sjöfallet National Park topographic map-fr.svg|thumb|Map of Sarek National Park, Padjelanta and Stora Sjöfallet]]
=== Location and borders === Sarek National Park is situated in the [[Jokkmokk Municipality]], [[Norrbotten County]], Sweden, north of the [[Arctic Circle]], {{convert|50|km|mi|2|abbr=on}} from the Norwegian border.
The area of the park is {{convert|1977|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} and it is adjacent to the national parks [[Padjelanta National Park|Padjelanta]] (in the west) and [[Stora Sjöfallet National Park|Stora Sjöfallet]] (in the north). The parks have a combined area of approximately {{convert|5500|km2|mi2|abbr=on}}. There are also a number of [[nature reserve]]s nearby.
=== Topography === [[File:Piellorieppe-rapaselet-25.jpg|thumb|The Piellorieppe massif and the Rapadalen valley]]
Sarek National Park is the most mountainous region in Sweden and it is the part of the country that mostly resembles an alpine countryside.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl10">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=10}}</ref> Within the park are 19 summits higher than {{convert|1900|m|ft|abbr=on}},<ref name="Curry-Lindahl11">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=11}}</ref> the most noted being the second highest summit in Sweden after the [[Kebnekaise]] – the [[Sarektjåkkå]] with a height of {{convert|2089|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name=britannica>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/524215/Sarek-National-Park|work=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]|title=Sarek National Park|accessdate=26 October 2011}}</ref> The lowest altitude in the park is found in the southwest, near Lake Rittakjaure, at {{convert|477|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl11" />
The park is made up of three types of landscape, sometimes difficult to differentiate between: large valleys, massive mountains, and high plateaux.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl97">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=97}}</ref> The largest valley of the park, which is also the most noted, is the [[Rapa Valley]].<ref name="Curry-Lindahl102">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=102}}</ref> This valley occupies {{convert|40|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}<ref name="Curry-Lindahl99">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=99}}</ref> of the park, including several branches, the most important of which are the Sarvesvagge, which climbs as far as Padjelanta,<ref name="Curry-Lindahl106">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=106}}</ref> the Kuopervagge — with an area of nearly {{convert|20|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} — and the Ruotesvagge, surrounded by numerous glaciers, including those of Mount Sarektjåkkå.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl110">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=110}}</ref> Among the other notable valleys, outside the Rapadalen network, are the Kukkesvagge that makes up the north-eastern border of the park,<ref name="Curry-Lindahl110" /> and the Njåtsosvagge near the southern border.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl97" /> The largest plateau is the Ivarlako, east of the Pårte [[massif]], with an altitude starting at {{convert|660|-|850|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl112">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=112}}</ref> West of Pårte, the Luottolako plateau covers an area of {{convert|45|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and has an even higher altitude at {{convert|1200|-|1400|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl112" />
[[File:Sarek National Park Worldwind-2.png|thumb|upright=1.8|Relief image of the park from the southeast, with Pårte and its glaciers in the front of the picture.]] Interspersed between the valleys and the plateaux, are massive mountains, often with several summits. The main ones are: *Sarektjåkkå, highest point: Stortoppen, {{convert|2089|m|ft|abbr=on}} *Pårte, Pårtetjåkkå, {{convert|2005|m|ft|abbr=on}} *Piellorieppe, Kåtokkaskatjåkkå, {{convert|1978|m|ft|abbr=on}} *Ålkatj, (Akkatjåkko, {{convert|1974|m|ft|abbr=on}} *Äpar, {{convert|1914|m|ft|abbr=on}} *Skårki, {{convert|1842|m|ft|abbr=on}} *Ruotes, {{convert|1804|m|ft|abbr=on}}
=== Climate === {{Weather box |location = Ritsem |metric first = Y |single line = Y |source=Swedish institute of metrology and hydrology (SMHI)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.smhi.se/met/climate/time_series/month_year/normal_1961_1990/SMHI_month_year_normal_61_90_temperature_celsius.txt|work=SMHI|title=Normalvärden för temperatur för 1961–1990|accessdate=26 October 2011}} : station 17793 (Ritsem A)</ref>{{,}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.smhi.se/met/climate/time_series/month_year/normal_1961_1990/SMHI_month_year_normal_61_90_precipitation_mm.txt|work=SMHI|title=Normalvärden för nederbörd för 1961–1990|accessdate=26 October 2011}} : station 17793 (Ritsem A)</ref> |Jan mean C = -11.5 |Feb mean C = -10.2 |Mar mean C = -8.2 |Apr mean C = -3.7 |May mean C = 2.2 |Jun mean C = 7.9 |Jul mean C = 10.7 |Aug mean C = 9.4 |Sep mean C = 5.3 |Oct mean C = 0.4 |Nov mean C = -5.3 |Dec mean C = -8.8 |year mean C = -1.0 |date=March 2012}}
=== Hydrography === The park's main river is the Rapa River (''Rapaätno''). It originates from the [[glacier]]s of Sarektjåkkå and runs down the Rapa Valley as far as [[Laitaure|Lake Laitaure]], and continues outside the park,<ref name="Curry-Lindahl99" /> where it joins with the [[Lesser Lule River]] which becomes a tributary of the [[Lule River]] at its confluence.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl99" /> This river is fed by thirty glaciers, contributing to a significant flow. The specific flow, the ratio between the average flow and the [[drainage basin]], from these waters, is the most significant in Sweden.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl30">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=30}}</ref> The flow fluctuates strongly with the seasons, having an average of 100 m<sup>3</sup>⋅s<sup>−1</sup> in July and about 4 m<sup>3</sup>⋅s<sup>−1</sup> in winter, resulting in an average annual flow of approximately 30 m<sup>3</sup>⋅s<sup>−1</sup>.<ref name=rapahydro>{{citation|title=The Laitaure Delta: A Study of Deltaic Morphology and Processes|first1=Valter|last1=Axelsson|author-link=Valter Axelsson|journal=[[Geografiska Annaler]] |series=Series A, Physical Geography |volume=49|issue=1|year=1967|pages=1–127|doi=10.2307/520865}}</ref> The river also transports a significant quantity of [[sediment]]. In summer, it can carry up to {{convert|5000|-|10000|MT|lb}} of sediment daily. In winter it only carries a few tons every day, resulting in an annual total of {{convert|180000|MT|lb}}.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl31">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=31}}</ref> The sediment gives the river a grey-green colour and forms large [[River delta|deltas]].<ref name="Curry-Lindahl30" /> The main delta is formed at the confluence of the Rapaätno with its principal tributary, the river Sarvesjokk.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl99" />
Just before the confluence, the river [[Braided river|braids]] for nearly {{convert|10|km|mi|abbr=on}}, forming a zone called Rapaselet.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl100">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=100}}</ref> The most noted of the deltas – and an emblem of the park – is the Laitaure delta (''Laitauredeltat''), which the river forms as it connects with Lake Laitaure.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl99" /> The other significant rivers correspond to the principal valleys listed above. Most of them make up the drainage basin of Lesser Lule River. The rivers in the north part of the park flow into Lake [[Akkajaure]], in the Stora Sjöfallet National Park, forming part of the hydrographic network of Lule älv.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl30" />
The park also contains several lakes.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl21">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=21}}</ref> The largest are the Alkajaure (altitude {{convert|751|m|ft|abbr=on|disp=or}}), on the border between the Sarek and the Padjelanta park, and the Pierikjaure (altitude {{convert|820|m|ft|abbr=on|disp=or}}) near the Stora Sjöfallet National Park.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl29">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=29}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="160px" caption="The landscapes of Rapa River"> File:Rapaselet-from-piellorieppe.jpg|Rapaselet File:Rapaselet (1994-09-03).jpg|Skyview of Rapaselet File:Laitaure ASTER 2002-08-09.jpg|The river delta of Laitaure </gallery>
== Geology ==
=== Formation === [[File:Alkavagge-Kuoper.jpg|thumb|Alggavagge, in Sarek National Park. The Scandinavian Mountains were made by an ancient plateau being strongly eroded.]]
The Sarek National Park lies within the [[Scandinavian Mountains]], a mountain chain whose origin is still a matter debate.<ref name=MedHar2015>{{cite journal |last=Medvedev |first=Sergei |last2=Hartz |first2=Ebbe H. |date=2015 |title=Evolution of topography of post-Devonian Scandinavia: Effects and rates of erosion |url= |journal=[[Geomorphology (journal)|Geomorphology]] |volume=231 |issue= |pages= 229–245 |doi= 10.1016/j.geomorph.2014.12.010|access-date= }}</ref> The rocks of the Scandinavian Mountains were put in place by the [[Caledonian orogeny]],<ref name=Lundqvistetal2011/> forming a belt of deformed and displaced rocks now known as the [[Scandinavian Caledonides]]. Caledonian rocks overlie rocks of the much older [[Svecofennian orogeny|Svecokarelian]] and [[Sveconorwegian orogeny|Sveconorwegian]] [[province (geology)|provinces]]. The Caledonian rocks actually form large [[nappe]]s ({{lang-sv|skollor}}) that have been [[thrust fault|thrusted over]] the older rocks. Much of the Caledonian rocks have been eroded since they were put in place meaning that they were once thicker and more contiguous. It is also implyed from the erosion that the nappes of Caledonian rock reached once further east than they do today. The erosion has left remaining massifs of Caledonian rocks and [[window (geology)|windows]] of Precambrian rock.<ref name=Lundqvistetal2011>{{cite book |last1=Lundqvist |first1=Jan |last2=Lundqvist |first2=Thomas |last3=Lindström |first3=Maurits |last4=Calner |first4=Mikael|last5=Sivhed |first5=Ulf |author-link1=Jan Lundqvist |author-link2=Thomas Lundqvist (geologist)|author-link3=Maurits Lindström|edition=3rd |date=2011 |title=Sveriges Geologi: Från urtid till nutid |chapter=Fjällen |language=Swedish |location=Spain |publisher=[[Studentlitteratur]] |isbn=978-91-44-05847-4 |via= |subscription= |quote=|pages=323–340 }}</ref> The Caledonian orogeny resulted from the collision of the [[Laurentia]] and [[Baltica]] [[Plate tectonics|plates]], 450 to 250 million years ago, with the disappearance of the [[Iapetus Ocean]] by [[subduction]].<ref name=uplift_alt>{{citation|title=The evolution of western Scandinavian topography: A review of Neogene uplift versus the ICE (isostasy–climate–erosion) hypothesis|author1=Søren B. Nielsen |author2=Kerry Gallagher |author3=Callum Leighton |author4=Niels Balling |author5=Lasse Svenningsen |author6=Bo Holm Jacobsen |author7=Erik Thomsen |author8=Ole B. Nielsen |author9=Claus Heilmann-Clausen |author10=David L. Egholm |author11=Michael A. Summerfield |author12=Ole Rønø Clausen |author13=Jan A. Piotrowski |author14=Marianne R. Thorsen |author15=Mads Huuse |author16=Niels Abrahamsen |author17=Chris King |author18=Holger Lykke-Andersen |journal=Journal of Geodynamics| volume=47|year=2009|pages=72–95| doi=10.1016/j.jog.2008.09.001}}</ref> This happened just before the formation of the chain and was caused by the appearance of a [[rift]], which finally led to the creation of the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name=uplift_alt /> The chain, once split open, continued to erode until it formed a [[peneplain]].<ref name="Curry-Lindahl12">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=12}}</ref>
Starting about 60 million years ago, both the Scandinavian and the North-American sections suffered a [[tectonic uplift]].<ref name=uplift>{{citation|title=Neogene uplift and tectonics around the North Atlantic: overview|first1=Peter|last1=Japsen|first2=James A.|last2=Chalmers|journal=Global and Planetary Change|volume=24|year=2000|pages=165–173|doi=10.1016/s0921-8181(00)00006-0}}</ref> It is unclear what causes this and several hypotheses have been presented.<ref name=uplift /> One of the theories is the influence of the [[Iceland hotspot]] which could have raised the crust.<ref name=uplift /> Another hypothesis is the [[isostasy]] related to [[Glacial period|glaciations]] caused the uplift.<ref name=uplift /> In any of those cases, the uplift allowed the ancient mountain chain to rise several thousand metres.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl12" />
The area of the national park, and the eastern Sarek Mountains in particular, was the last of part of [[Fennoscandia]] to be [[deglaciation|deglaciated]]. The last remnants of the [[Fennoscandian Ice Sheet]] melted there slightly after 9,700 years [[before present|BP]].<ref>{{cite journal|author-last=Stroeven|author-first=Arjen P. |author-last2=Hättestrand|author-first2=Clas |author-last3=Kleman|author-first3=Johan|author-last4=Heyman|author-first4=Jakob |author-last5=Fabel|author-first5=Derek |author-last6=Fredin|author-first6=Ola |author-last7=Goodfellow|author-first7=Bradley W. |author-last8=Harbor|author-first8=Jonathan M. |author-last9=Jansen|author-first9=John D. |author-last10=Olsen|author-first10=Lars |author-last11=Caffee|author-first11=Marc W. |author-last12=Fink|author-first12=David |author-last13=Lundqvist|author-first13=Jan |author-last14=Rosqvist|author-first14=Gunhild C. |author-last15=Strömberg|author-first15=Bo |author-last16=Jansson|author-first16=Krister N. |author-link13=Jan Lundqvist |date=2016|title=Deglaciation of Fennoscandia|journal=[[Quaternary Science Reviews]] |volume=147|issue=|pages=91–121}}</ref>
=== Erosion === [[File:Mikkaglaciären-övre-del-25.jpg|thumb|The glacier Mikka on Sarektjåkkå]] The mountain chain was renewed and after that it was subjected to a new period of glacial erosion.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl12" /> In the beginning of the [[Quaternary]] period, 15 million years ago, a significant [[Glacial motion|glacial advance]] occurred.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl13" /> The glaciers began to grow and move into the valleys where they gradually merged to form an [[ice sheet]] that covered the entire region.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl13">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=13}}</ref> Several further glaciations followed, forming the current landscape, with glacial valleys, [[cirque]]s, [[nunatak]]s etc.<ref name="Abrahamsson57" /> The degree to which the chain was affected by the erosion depended mainly on the structure of the terrain, which explains the diversity in the topography of the area. The topography of Sarek, similar to that of Kebnekaise, is divided into sharply defined zones, particularly in respect to the two neighbouring national parks. This is mainly due to the existence of [[diabase]] and [[diorite]] [[dike (geology)|dikes]] which are more resistant to erosion.<ref name=kebnekaise_geol>{{citation|title=Bedrock Geology and Morphology of the Tarfala Area, Kebnekaise Mts., Swedish Caledonides|journal=Geografiska Annaler. Series A, Physical Geography|first1=Per-Gunnar|last1=Andréasson|first2=David G.|last2=Gee|volume=71|year=1989|pages=235–239|doi=10.2307/521393}}</ref> The park is intersected by a tangle of dikes created 608 million years ago, an era that probably corresponds with the first appearance of the rift during the formation of the Iapetus ocean.<ref name=dyke>{{citation|title=Onset of seafloor spreading in the Iapetus Ocean at 608 Ma: precise age of the Sarek Dyke Swarm, northern Swedish Caledonides|first1=O.M.|last1=Svenningsen|journal=Precambrian Research|volume=110|year=2001|pages=241–254|doi=10.1016/s0301-9268(01)00189-9}}</ref> These dikes represent intrusions into the Sarektjåkkå [[nappe]], which is composed of sediments probably deposited in the rift basin.<ref name=nappe>{{citation|title=Extensional deformation along the Late Precambrian-Cambrian Baltoscandian passive margin : the Sarektjåkkå nappe, Swedish Caledonides|first1=O.M.|last1=Svenningsen|journal=Geol Rundsch|year=1995|volume=84|pages=649–664|doi=10.1007/s005310050031}}</ref>
=== Glaciers === [[File:Pårte ASTER 2008-09-02.jpg|thumb|Pårte with its characteristic glaciers]] The park has over 100 glaciers, making it one of the most glacier-rich areas in Sweden. The glaciers are relatively small, the largest being Pårtejekna in Pårte at {{convert|11|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. However, some of the others are relatively large for Sweden, since the largest Swedish glacier, [[Stuorrajekna]] in [[Sulitjelma (mountain)|Sulitelma]] (south of Padjelanta), measures {{convert|13|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Abrahamsson57">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=57}}</ref>
The evolution of the glaciers, particularly that of the Mikka ({{convert|8|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}})<ref name="Abrahamsson56">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=56}}</ref> have been studied since the end of the 19th century, especially by mineralogist and geographer [[Axel Hamberg]].<ref name="Abrahamsson29">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=29}}</ref> The other glaciers in the park have an evolution similar to that of the Mikka: in 1883 to 1895 they were mostly receding, then advanced a little in 1900 to 1916, after which they started to recede again.<ref name=glacier>{{citation|title=Holocene glacial variations in Sarek National Park, northern Sweden|first1=Wibjörn|last1=Karlén|first2=George H.|last2=Denton|journal=Boreas|volume=5|pages=25–56|year=1975|doi=10.1111/j.1502-3885.1976.tb00329.x}}</ref> Later they stabilised or grew, which was interpreted as being caused by the increase in winter precipitation related to [[global warming]]. The effect of the raised summer temperatures has been taken into account when assessing the data.<ref name=kebneglacier>{{citation|title=Fifty Years of Mass Balance and Glacier Front Observations at the Tarfala Research Station|journal=Geografiska Annaler. Series A, Physical Geography|first1=Per|last1=Holmlund|first2=Wibjörn|last2=Karlén|first3=Håkan|last3=Grudd|volume=78|year=1996|page=105|doi=10.2307/520972}}</ref> The receding of the glaciers has resumed at a particularly rapid pace during the first years of the 21st century.<ref name=forsvinner>{{cite news|url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/sareks-glaciarer-forsvinner-fort_1641495.svd|newspaper=[[Svenska Dagbladet]]|title=Sareks glaciärer försvinner fort|date=30 August 2008|first1=Susanna|last1=Baltscheffsky|language=Swedish}}</ref>
== Wildlife == According to its [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] classification, Sarek National Park is situated in the [[Scandinavian Montane Birch forest and grasslands]] [[ecoregion]], with a minor section in the [[Scandinavian and Russian taiga]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalspecies.org/protectareas/display/23067 |title=Protected Area : Sarek |publisher=Global Species |date= |accessdate=2012-01-21}}</ref> With regards to the flora and fauna, Sarek does not have a wide variety of species.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl53">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=53}}</ref> This is mainly explained by the fact that most of the park, except the south and south-east part,<ref name="Curry-Lindahl11" /> is above the growth-limit of conifers,<ref name="Curry-Lindahl53" /> which is at an altitude of about {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} in this region.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl20">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=20}}</ref> Adding to this, unlike most of the region, Sarek National Park has few vast lakes or [[swamp]]s.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl53" /> A total of approximately 380 species of [[vascular plant]]s have been found in the park,<ref name="Curry-Lindahl33">{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=33}}</ref> as well as 182 species of [[vertebrate]]s, 24 [[mammal]]s, 142 [[bird]]s, 2 [[reptile]]s, 2 [[amphibian]]s and 12 [[fish]].<ref name="Curry-Lindahl53" /> Many of these species are on the Swedish [[IUCN Red List|red list]] of [[endangered species]], notably the large carnivores.
The vegetation follows a fairly strict [[altitudinal zonation]], as a result of the climate, and implying a similar zonation of [[fauna]], although this is often less strict.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl53" />
=== Montane zone === The [[Montane ecology#Montane forests|montane zones]] are relatively rare in the park, as its upper limit is about {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} below most altitudes in these northern [[latitude]]s. The flora of this zone is constituted by [[old-growth forest]]s of conifers, with mainly [[Scots pine]]s and including [[Picea abies|Norway spruces]]. The pines can become very tall, particularly those around Lake Rittak, in the south part of the park. The undergrowth is mostly covered with [[moss]]es and [[lichen]]s, in particular [[Cladonia rangiferina|reindeer lichen]], and also with ''[[Vaccinium myrtillus]]'', ''[[Empetrum nigrum]]'' and [[Vaccinium vitis-idaea|cowberry]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
The Sarek forests are a preferred habitat for numerous species of animals. Among the large carnivores, the [[brown bear]] is particularly frequent in the park and in the neighbouring Stora Sjöfallet. The bear fairly often also ventures into the subalpine region. The [[Eurasian lynx]], classed as an endangered species in Sweden, is also found around the lakes of Rittak and Laitaure, and is also found in the subalpine forests of Rapa Valley. The [[red fox]] is relatively frequent, and is gradually extending its territory into the higher zones, where it competes with the [[arctic fox]]. Some small mammals that are frequent in the park are the [[European pine marten]], the [[least weasel]] and the [[stoat]]. The ermine is also found in the higher regions. The herbivores include a very large number of [[moose]] as the forests and humid zones provide them with lots of food.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl64>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=64}}</ref> They often grow to an impressive size in the park, with enormous [[antler]]s.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl65>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=65}}</ref>
The birds in Sarek include a number of [[owl]]s, such as the [[Ural owl]], and [[woodpecker]]s, particularly the [[Eurasian three-toed woodpecker]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl67>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=67}}</ref> The [[grey-headed chickadee]] is also very common, as are the [[fieldfare]], the [[song thrush]] and the [[redwing]]. Reptiles and amphibians, such as the [[viviparous lizard]], the [[common frog]] and the [[Vipera berus|common European viper]], are mostly found in the forests.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl68>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=68}}</ref> The vipers of the Rittak region frequently reach remarkable sizes.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl68 />
=== Subalpine zone === [[File:Piellorieppe-äng-25.jpg|thumb|left|Prairie and forest in the [[Rapa Valley]]]] The [[Montane ecology#Subalpine zone|subalpine zone]] mostly consists of old-growth [[birch]] forests.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl36>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=36}}</ref> These forests are exceptional in terms of density and richness, making it possible for significant quantities of sediment material to be carried from the mountainside by the runoff and deposited in the watercourses.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl37>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=37}}</ref> This kind of transfer is particularly noted in the Rapa Valley.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl37 /> In general, the transition between the conifer forests and the ones consisting of birch is more or less gradual, with the number of birches present in the coniferous forests increasing along with the altitude until the conifers have completely disappeared.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl34>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=34}}</ref> The size of the trees also diminishes with increasing altitude.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl41>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=41}}</ref> The upper altitude limit for the forests — which is also the [[tree line]] varies greatly throughout the park, from {{convert|600|m|ft|abbr=on}} in the Tjoulta valley to over {{convert|800|m|ft|abbr=on}} in the Rapa Valley.<ref name="Curry-Lindahl21" />
The birch forests also contain other species of trees. The number of [[rowan]], [[Alnus incana|grey alder]], [[Populus tremula|trembling poplar]] and [[Prunus padus|hackberry]] is relatively high.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl37 /> The [[Cicerbita alpina|alpine blue-sow-thistle]] is very widespread in this zone and is the food the bears prefer.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl37 /> [[Angelica archangelica|Garden angelica]] also grows in the forests, reaching a height of {{convert|2|to|3|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl37 /> Many other plants in this zone can also attain exceptional size.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl38>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=38}}</ref>
[[File:Sarek delta.jpg|thumb|A reindeer in a valley in Sarek]] The division between the birch and coniferous forests is relatively blurred, with many of the animal species listed above also present in the subalpine zone.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl69>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=69}}</ref> Some small mammals are found more frequently here than in the coniferous forests, particularly several rodents such as the [[common shrew]] and the [[field vole]]. This is also the [[reindeer]]s' habitat.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl70>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=70}}</ref> The [[Sami people]] living within the borders of the park, have domesticated the reindeer that stay in this zone during spring and move up to the alpine zone in summer.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl70 /> Brown bears are common in the valleys of Tjoulta and Rapadalen.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl71>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=71}}</ref> However, it is the quantity and variety of birds is that enriches this zone.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl72>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=72}}</ref> The [[willow warbler]], the [[common redpoll]], the [[brambling]], the [[Western yellow wagtail|yellow wagtail]], the [[northern wheatear]] and the [[bluethroat]] are characteristic of the birch forests.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl72 /> The [[willow ptarmigan]] is also more common in this area.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl73>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=73}}</ref> The [[Bird of prey|raptors]] present in the zone are the [[Merlin (bird)|merlin]] and the [[rough-legged buzzard]], which often nests on the cliffs.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl72 /> The [[gyrfalcon]] and the [[golden eagle]] usually prefer lower altitudes, but are nevertheless also found in the park.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl77>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=77}}</ref>
=== Alpine zone === [[File:Sarek Flower path.jpg|thumb|A flowery prairie of alpine [[Cicerbita alpina|blue-sow-thistle]] on the slopes of the park]]
The [[Alpine tundra|alpine zone]] is divided into several narrower zones.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl42>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=42}}</ref> The first subzone is mostly characterized by [[heath]]land, with many [[alder]] [[shrub]]s, mosses and lichens, and frequently dense mats of [[Empetrum nigrum|crowberries]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl42 /> Different types of heaths can be distinguished. One type is mostly composed of a mix of [[Diphasiastrum alpinum|alpine clubmoss]] and [[Arctostaphylos alpina|alpine bearberry]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl43>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=43}}</ref> [[Silene acaulis|Cushion pink]] and [[Pedicularis|Lapland lousewort]] bring autumn colour to the heaths, which are otherwise fairly monocrome.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl43 /> In the chalky soils of this subzone, the vegetation is very rich and forms [[prairie]]s with [[Dryas octopetala|mountain avens]] as the most characteristic species. [[Saxifraga oppositifolia|purple saxifrage]], [[Bartsia alpina|velvetbells]], [[Antennaria alpina|alpine pussytoes]] and [[alpine veronica]] are also present.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl43 /> With increasing altitude, the [[Salix herbacea|dwarf willow]] and [[lichen]]s become more prominent, forming a second zone.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl46>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=46}}</ref> Gradually the plants become more scarce, and above {{convert|1500|m|ft|abbr=on}} there are only 18 types of plants present.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl47>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=47}}</ref>
There are three rare mammals who live in this zone. The [[wolverine]] inhabits a vast territory, roaming as far as the coniferous forests in winter, but the alpine zone is their main territory.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl87>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=87}}</ref> They mostly eat [[carrion]], but they do also hunt living animals such as small rodents, birds and insects.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl87 /> The wolverine is labelled as an endangered species in Sweden with an estimate of 360 individuals in the country in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcie.org/Docs/Action%20Plans/Swedish%20Wolverine%20Action%20Plan.pdf|title=Åtgärdsprogram för bevarande av Järv|author=[[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)|Swedish Environmental Protection Agency]]|year=2000|language=Swedish}}</ref> The Arctic fox is a [[critically endangered]] species in Sweden, with only 50 individuals in the whole country.<ref name=renard>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturvardsverket.se/Documents/publikationer/978-91-620-5927-9.pdf|title=Åtgärdsprogram för fjällräv 2008–2012|author=Naturvårdsverket|year=2008|language=Swedish}}</ref> They dig extensive networks of tunnels in areas above the tree-line, with several families inhabiting the same [[sett]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl87 /> The park is one of the last sanctuaries for the [[gray wolf]],<ref name=Curry-Lindahl87 /> a species also critically endangered in Sweden.<ref name=varg>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcie.org/Docs/Action%20Plans/Swedish%20Wolf%20Action%20Plan.pdf|title=Åtgärdsprogram för bevarande av Varg|author=Naturvårdsverket|year=2003|language=Swedish}}</ref> In 1974–1975, the park was home to the only remaining wild wolf living in Sweden.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rovdyr.org/arkiv/toverud_bok.pdf|work=Rovdur|title=Utsettning av ulv i Norge og Sverige|accessdate=29 October 2011|language=Norwegian}}</ref> Although the wolf population is now growing,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Attitudes of hunters, locals, and the general public in Sweden now that the wolves are back|publisher=Biological Conservation|volume=111|year=2003|pages=149–159|first1=Göran|last1=Ericsson|first2=Thomas A.|last2=Heberlein}}</ref> they have not yet achieved a stable number in the park.<ref name=laponia>{{cite web|url=http://www.laponia.info/media/620.pdf|title=Strategiska frågor för utveckling av Världsarvet Laponia|work=Laponia|accessdate=29 October 2011|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050106045109/http://www.laponia.info/media/620.pdf|archivedate=6 January 2005|df=}}</ref>
In addition to these three mammals, [[Norway lemming]]s are also found in the park.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl88>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|pp=88–91}}</ref> The number of lemmings varies extremely, with massive spikes in the population during some years, immediately followed by a very rapid decline. This phenomenon is not completely understood; it appears that favourable weather, and therefore a surplus of food, results in sudden population growths, but the reason for the decline is less obvious, although it is certain that contagious diseases play some role.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl88 /> These cycles are also reflected in the populations of animals who prey on the lemmings.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl88 />
Many birds living at this altitude are associated with the humid zones. However, the alpine zone has its own characteristic species, such as the [[rock ptarmigan]],<ref name=Curry-Lindahl88 /> the [[snowy owl]], the [[horned lark]], the [[meadow pipit]], the [[snow bunting]]<ref name=Curry-Lindahl95>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=95}}</ref> and the [[Lapland longspur]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl85>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=85}}</ref>
=== Humid zone === [[File:Sarek cotton grass.jpg|thumb|[[Eriophorum|Cotton grass]] in the national park]] Although the park does not have the vast marshes and lakes characteristic of the rest of the region, water is nevertheless present everywhere. The humid zones are rich with a great diversity of flora and fauna. The stratification of vegetation is just as valid in the humid zones. In the montane region, the humid soils are covered with flowers such as the [[Rhododendron tomentosum|northern Labrador tea]], [[Eriophorum|cottonsedge]], the [[Ranunculus auricomus|Goldilocks buttercup]], [[Moneses|St Olaf's candlestick]], [[Prunella vulgaris|common selfheal]] and [[Galium palustre|common marsh-bedstraw]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl35>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=35}}</ref> In the subalpine zone, the humid prairies mainly have mats of [[Trollius europaeus|Globe-flower]], [[Caltha palustris|kingcup]] and [[Viola biflora|twoflower violet]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl37 /> In the alpine region there are many subalpine plants as well as the ''[[Pedicularis sceptrum-carolinum]]'',<ref name=Curry-Lindahl43 /> and the vegetation decreases as the altitude increases.
The humid zones of the park are well known for their rich diversity of birds. The [[common crane]], the [[wood sandpiper]] and the [[short-eared owl]] are found at the lower altitudes,<ref name=Curry-Lindahl67 /> while the [[Eurasian teal]], the [[Eurasian wigeon]], the [[greater scaup]], the [[red-breasted merganser]], the [[sedge warbler]] and the [[common reed bunting]] are common in the Laitaure delta and around Pårekjaure Lake.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl73 />
At higher altitudes, Vardojaure Lake is rich with birds, mostly ducks and also the [[European golden plover]], characteristic of the alpine zone and sometimes found in the humid zones.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl78>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=78}}</ref> Låotakjaure Lake, on the border of Padjelanta, is interesting from an ornithological point of view.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl79>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|pp=79–81}}</ref> Other rare species are also present, such as the [[lesser white-fronted goose]], the [[great snipe]], the [[red-throated pipit]], the [[long-tailed duck]] and the [[bar-tailed godwit]].<ref name=Curry-Lindahl79 /> The Luottolako Plateau is also considered to be interesting, with the most significant concentration of [[purple sandpiper]]s in Sweden.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl93>{{harvnb|Curry-Lindahl|1968|p=93}}</ref>
[[Arctic char]]s, trouts and [[common minnow]]s are found in the park's lakes, rivers and streams.<ref name=Curry-Lindahl69 /><ref name=Curry-Lindahl77 />
== Tourism == Sarek National Park is mainly a high-alpine area with almost no accommodation for tourists.<ref name="naturvardsverket.se">{{cite web|title=Sarek|publisher=[[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)]]|url=http://www.naturvardsverket.se/sv/Start/Friluftsliv/Skyddade-omraden/Nationalparker/Sarek/|accessdate=20 February 2012}}</ref>
=== Hiking trails === The [[Kungsleden]] hiking trail passes through the eastern part of the park, from [[Saltoluokta]] to [[Kvikkjokk]]. There are no cabins within the park, the Pårte, Aktse and Sitojaure cabins are just outside the park and they are accessible from both Saltoluokta and Kvikkjokk.
The Padjelanta Trail (''Padjelantaleden''), running from Kvikkjokk to Akkajaure, skirts the park along its western rim at Tarraluoppal, where the Tarraluoppal cabin is just on the border of the park.
=== Hazards === Due to the lack of [[Shelter (building)|shelters]] combined with rapidly shifting weather and rough terrain, it is recommended that hikers are well prepared and experienced before setting out on the trails of the park.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kläder och utrustning|trans-title=Clothes and equipment|url=http://www.sverigesnationalparker.se/park/sarek-nationalpark/besoksinformation/klader-och-utrustning/#.VcxzHmzovIV|website=www.sverigesnationalparker.se|publisher=[[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)]]|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref>
==== Fording streams ==== There are few bridges in the park, and crossing streams (Sami: ''jokk'') and rivers (Sami: ''ätno'') can be dangerous for ill-equipped or inexperienced hikers. Warm weather increases the melting of the glaciers causing water levels to rise, therefore wading is often easier and safer early in the morning.<ref name="naturvardsverket.se" />
The only [[Ford (crossing)|ford]] across the Rapa River south of the Smaila Moot, is at Tielmaskaite. The ford is long and can only be used when waterlevels are low. Inexperienced hikers are recommended not to cross without a guide.
The glacier ''jokk'' from Pårtejekna, Kåtokjåhkå, has no fords. There is a bridge at the southernmost part of the stream ({{coord|67|09|25.9|N|17|51|20.9|E|region:SE_type:landmark|display=inline}}). Hikers can also follow the streams up to the glacier and cross there, although this requires knowledge about glacier crossing.
==== Sarek in the winter ==== The lack of marked trails and accommodations makes it very difficult for visitors to hike in the park in winter, unless they are experienced and properly equipped. The steep slopes of the valleys also contributes to the risk for [[avalanche]]s.<ref name="naturvardsverket.se" />
=== Places of interest ===
==== Aktse ==== Aktse is an old farm settlement on the Kungsleden trail, approximately {{convert|1.3|km|mi|abbr=on}} outside the boundaries of the park.
==== Alkavare ==== In 1788 a chapel was built at Alkavare ({{coord|67|20|32.7|N|17|12|55.3|E|region:SE_type:landmark|display=inline}}) for the Sami that were herding reindeer in the area during summer. The walls of the building were dry set from local stone and the roof was made of timber, transported from Kvikkjokk, {{convert|60|km|mi|abbr=on}} away. Originally, service was held every summer on June{{nbsp}}25. It took the minister from Kvikkjokk three days to reach the chapel, and three days to get back. It was abandoned in the mid-19th century and renovated in 1961, and is still in use. {{As of|2015}}, it belongs to the [[Jokkmokk]] parish of the [[Church of Sweden]], and church service is held throughout July.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alkavare kapell|url=http://www.svenskakyrkan.se/default.aspx?id=660695|website=www.svenskakyrkan.se|publisher=[[Church of Sweden]]|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hamberg|first1=Axel|title=Alkavare lappkapell: en kulturbild|journal=Svenska turistföreningens årsskrift|volume=1926|date=1926|publisher=[[Svenska Turistföreningen]]|pages=263–272|url=http://www.axelhamberg.se/pdf/Hamberg_AlkavareLappkapell.pdf|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref>
==== The Smaila Moot ==== Just above the canyon, formed by Smailajåkk as it descends toward Rapaätno, there is a cabin for the National Park Service ({{coord|67|22|38|N|17|38|42|E|region:SE_type:landmark|display=inline}}). There is also a bridge over the Smailajåkk canyon which allows hikers to cross the stream safely. The bridge is removed every winter and put back in the spring, after the spring flood. The cabin is not open to hikers, but there is an emergency shelter as well as an emergency telephone and an outhouse there. The presence of the bridge and the fact that three of the major valleys in the park (''Routesvagge'', Rapa Valley and ''Koupervagge'') converge there, has resulted in the name 'Smaila Moot' for the location which has become a meeting place for hikers in the park. It is also a preferred location to start a climb to the top of the Sarektjåkkå ({{convert|2089|m|ft|abbr=on}}), via the Mikkajekna glacier.
==== Pastavagge ==== Pastavagge (in [[Lule Sami language|Lule Sami]] [[Orthography]] called ''Basstavágge'') is a narrow valley, forming a pass, running from Pielavalta (''Bielavallda'') towards the east, ending north of Rinim on the shores of Lake Sitojaure (''Sijddojávrre''). The trekking distance from Pielvalta to Rinim is about {{convert|18|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://kso2.lantmateriet.se/#|title = Topografisk karta|date = 2015-03-16|accessdate = 2015-03-16|website =www.lantmateriet.se |publisher =[[Lantmäteriet]]}}</ref> As there is a boat connection between Rinim and the Sitojaure cabins on the Kungsleden,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.svenskaturistforeningen.se/sv/upptack/Omraden/Lappland/Fjallstugor/STF-Fjallstuga-ritsem/Hitta-hit/Battrafik-langs-lederna/|title = Båttrafik längs lederna |date = 2015-03-16|accessdate = 2015-03-16|website = www.svenskaturistforeningen.se|publisher = [[Svenska Turistföreningen]]}}</ref> Pastavagge is a preferred route to and from central Sarek. The difference in altitude between the eastern entrance of the valley and the highest level of the pass is about {{convert|750|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Because of the steep climb, multiple fords and the high-alpine terrain, it usually takes at least a full day for hikers to traverse the pass.
== History ==
=== The Sami people === {{related articles|Sami people|Sami shamanism}} [[File:Skierffe and Nammasj.jpg|thumb|left|Mount Skierfe (right) is a sacred Sami site]]
The region's first inhabitants arrived with the retreat of the inland seas 8,000 years ago.<ref name=Kihlberg30>{{harvnb|Kihlberg|1997|p=30}}</ref> They were [[nomad]]s who lived in Northern [[Scandinavia]], and probably ancestors of the Samis.<ref name=Kihlberg30 /> Initially they were [[hunter-gatherer]]s, living off reindeer.<ref name=UNESCO>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/fr/list/774|work=Patrimoine mondial de l'UNESCO|title=Région de Laponie|accessdate=30 October 2011|language=French, English}}</ref> For those people, the mountains often had religious connotations, and several were ''Sieidi'' (places of worship).<ref name=Kihlberg31>{{harvnb|Kihlberg|1997|pp=31–32}}</ref> [[Sacrifice|Offerings]], such as [[antler]]s from reindeer, were often made in those places.<ref name=Kihlberg31 /> One of the most significant ''Sieidi'' was situated at the foot of Mount Skierfe ({{convert|1179|m|ft|abbr=on}} high), at the entrance to the Rapa Valley.<ref name=Kihlberg31 /> Samis from the entire region gathered in this place for ceremonies.<ref name=Kihlberg31 /> Mount Apär itself, was believed to be the home of demons and legend tells of an illegitimate child's ghost inside it.<ref name=Kihlberg34>{{harvnb|Kihlberg|1997|p=34}}</ref>
Despite their hunter-gatherer way of life, the Samis kept some domesticated reindeer. They were milked and used for transport as well as other things.<ref name=laponia /> Towards the end of the 17th century, the number of domesticated reindeer increased, and the Samis began to harmonize their travelling with the reindeer's search for pasture. Eventually, hunting the reindeer gave way to [[Animal husbandry|farming]] them.<ref name=laponia /> The Samis in the mountains gradually developed a system of [[transhumance]] (movement between fixed summer and winter pastures).<ref name=laponia /> They spent the winters on the park's plains and moved up into the mountains in summer, mainly to Padjelanta.<ref name="Abrahamsson14">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=14}}</ref> Sarek was mostly used as a corridor for travels, although certain prairies (Skarja and Peilavalta in particular) were used for pasture.<ref name="Abrahamsson14" /> For shelter during their long journeys, which could last for several weeks, the inhabitants built huts (''kåta'') at selected places in the park.<ref name="Abrahamsson23">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=23}}</ref> Little by little, they left the reindeer to graze as they pleased, and stopped moving with the herds in the old way.<ref name=laponia />
=== Sarek and the Swedes === [[File:Kote-Parek.jpg|thumb|A [[Sami people|Sami]] home near Pårek]]
When the Swedish government took control over the Sami territory, the Sami had to pay the same taxes as other Swedes.<ref name=historia>{{cite web|url=http://www.laponia.info/media/727.pdf|work=Laponia|title=Historia i Laponia|accessdate=30 October 2011|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040729110724/http://www.laponia.info/media/727.pdf|archivedate=29 July 2004|df=}}</ref> In the 17th century the Sami were [[Evangelism|evangelized]] by the Swedes, who often built churches and markets in locations where the Sami traditionally stayed during winter.<ref name=historia />
The Swedes considered the mountains to be frightening and dangerous so they did not explore them.<ref name="Abrahamsson26">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=26}}</ref> When the first [[ore]] deposits were discovered in the region, the Swedes attempted to persuade the Sami to prospect for other ores in the mountains, in particular [[silver]].<ref name=alkavare>{{cite web|url=http://www.laplandica.com/2008/02/01/the-alkavare-silver-mine…/|work=Laplandica|title=The Alkavare Silver Mine…|accessdate=30 October 2011}}</ref> But in general, the Sami did not dare to reveal such information to the Swedes because they did not want to incur the disapproval of their fellow Sami.<ref name=alkavare /> An ore discovery was likely to result in the Sami being forced into near-slavery, working the mines and transporting the minerals.<ref name=alkavare /> The Alkavare deposit was an exception. Its existence was revealed to the Swedes by an extremely poor Sami, who became held in disdain by his tribe due to this.<ref name=alkavare /> The exploitation of the mine began in 1672, but it never rendered any profit and was abandoned in 1702.<ref name=alkavare /> A few attempts to reopen the mine has been made, but they have not been successful.<ref name=alkavare /> The ruins of two buildings and a little chapel are visible nearby the site.<ref name=alkavare />
The first Swede to scientifically explore the mountains was [[Carl Linnaeus|Carl von Linné]] in his [[expedition to Lapland]] in 1732.<ref name="Abrahamsson26" /> Later, in 1870, Gustaf Wilhelm Bucht [[Cartography|mapped]] the region.<ref name="Abrahamsson27">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=27}}</ref> Shortly after, in 1881, the Frenchman [[Charles Rabot]] became the first man to reach the summit of Sarektjåkkå.<ref name="Abrahamsson27" /> The 1890s marked the start of systematic scientific expeditions.<ref name="Abrahamsson28">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|pp=28–29}}</ref> Most noted is the work of Axel Hamberg, who had participated in an expedition to Greenland led by [[Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld]]. Hamberg began his study of the region in 1895.<ref name="Abrahamsson28" /> He studied the park, chiefly the glaciers, until his death in 1931.<ref name="Abrahamsson28" /> He created a high quality map and constructed five cabins in the park, known as the Pårte station, where he conducted his studies of Sarek.<ref name="Abrahamsson28" /> Axel Hamburg's work was particularly significant for widespread public recognition of the park.<ref name="Abrahamsson28" />
=== Protection === The 1872 creation of the world's first [[national park]] in [[Yellowstone National Park|Yellowstone]]<ref name=svnatpark>{{cite book|title=National parks of Sweden|first1=Claes|last1=Grundsten|isbn=978-91-7126-160-1|editor=Max Ström|place=Stockholm|year=2010}}</ref> started a universal momentum for the protection of nature. In Sweden, the [[List of polar explorers|polar explorer]] Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld became the first to propose using the new concept to protect areas of the Swedish landscape.<ref name=creation>{{cite web|url=http://www.turism.jokkmokk.se/media/21054/allting%20om%20jokkmokk%20nr%208.pdf|work=Jokkmokks kommun|title=Allting om Jokkmokk|accessdate=31 October 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> Axel Hamburg, Nordenskiöld and other scientists organized a plea for establishing Sweden's first national parks, Sarek in particular.<ref name=creation /> They convinced the Swedish botanist and member of the [[Riksdag]] Karl Starbäck from [[Uppsala University]] to raise the question in the Riksdag.<ref name=creation /> The proposition was accepted in May 1909, and the first nine national parks were established.<ref name=creation /> These were also the first in Europe. Among them were Sarek and its neighbour the Stora Sjöfallet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parcsnationaux.fr/Decouvrir-Visiter-Partager/Les-parcs-nationaux-dans-le-monde|work=Parcs nationaux|title=Les parcs nationaux dans le monde|accessdate=31 October 2011|language=French}}</ref> The reason given for establishing the park was, as stated in official protocols, to "preserve a high mountain landscape in its natural state".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lagboken.se/files/SFS/2011/110841.PDF|work=Lagbocken|title=Förordning om ändring i nationalparksförordningen (1987:938)|accessdate=25 January 2012|language=Swedish}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In the middle of the 20th century, with developments in [[hydroelectricity]] in Sweden, [[dam]]s were frequently built across the northern rivers of Sweden.<ref name="Abrahamsson39">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=39}}</ref> These barrages were also constructed in the national parks; the Stora Sjöfallet National Park lost nearly a third of its land area with the creation of a dam in 1919.<ref name="svnatpark" /> In 1961, an accord called the "Sarek peace" (''Freden i Sarek'') was forged, preventing hydroelectric developments in Sarek as well as in certain rivers, designated "national rivers".<ref name=energifragan>{{cite web|url=http://www.ne.se/energifrågan|work=[[Nationalencyklopedin]]|title=Energifrågan|accessdate=7 November 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> This also led to the establishing of Padjelanta National Park.<ref name=energifragan />
[[File:Sarek National Park Landsat image.jpg|thumb|The borders of the park]] In 1982, the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN) mentioned a vast zone including Sarek National Park in its tentative list of natural sites to be classified as [[World Heritage Site]]s by [[UNESCO]].<ref name=IUCN_laponia>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/advisory_body_evaluation/774.pdf|work=Patrimoine mondial|title=World heritage nomination — IUCN summary, the lapponian area (Sweden)|accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> Sweden proposed that part of this zone, the Sjaunja nature reserve, should be included in the list, and in 1990 the IUCN recommended an extension to the proposed area.<ref name=IUCN_laponia /> In 1996, Sarek Park was classed as a World Heritage Site including the adjoining areas of Padjelanta, Stora Sjöfallet, Sjaunja and Stubba nature reserves, [[Muddus National Park]] and three adjacent areas, making a total of {{convert|9400|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. The whole area was added to the World Heritage as a mixed site ("of cultural and natural value") called the [[Laponian area]].<ref name=UNESCO /> The park also became part of the [[Natura 2000]] network.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lansstyrelsen.se/norrbotten/SiteCollectionDocuments/Sv/djur-och-natur/skyddad-natur/Nationalparker/Bevarandeplan_SarekNP.pdf|work=Länsstyrelsen i Norrbotten|title=Bevarandeplan Natura 2000 Sarek SE0820185|accessdate=1 November 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> Being on the World Heritage list allowed the park to have its first protection plan. The plan was written with thorough consultation of the Sami, who had not been consulted when the park was established.<ref name=award>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturvardsverket.se/sv/Start/Naturvard/Nyheter/Samverkan-om-Laponia-far-WWF-pris/|work=Naturvårdsverket|title=Samverkan om Laponia får WWF-pris|accessdate=1 November 2011|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108061337/http://www.naturvardsverket.se/sv/Start/Naturvard/Nyheter/Samverkan-om-Laponia-far-WWF-pris/|archivedate=8 November 2011|df=}}</ref> The [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] paid for this process.<ref name=award />
The 2007 [[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)|Environmental Protection Agency]] plan for the national parks includes a plan to expand Sarek to incorporate the area of the Laitaure Delta and the Tjuoltadalen Valley to the south part of the park.<ref name=plan>{{cite book|url=http://www.naturvardsverket.se/upload/30_global_meny/02_aktuellt/Remisser/Nationalparksplan/N_remiss_nationalparksplan.pdf|author=[[Environmental Protection Agency (Sweden)]]|title=Nationalparksplan för Sverige – Utkast och remissversion|year=2007|language=Swedish}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This extension had already been proposed in the 1989 plan, but the situation changed with the World Heritage designation as the proposed extension would make up a sizable part of the Laponian Region.<ref name=plan />
=== History of tourism === Sarek National Park is viewed by many Swedes as one of the most beautiful landscapes of their country. The enthusiasm for it was started by Axel Hamberg's book on the park, presenting Sarek as the joy of the Swedish Lapland.<ref name="Abrahamsson37">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=37}}</ref>
The [[Svenska Turistföreningen|Swedish Tourist Association]] (STF) was created in 1885. In 1886, they mentioned Sarek as a potential tourist site for the first time.<ref name="Abrahamsson35">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=35}}</ref> However, the number of tourists was not more than a few dozen.<ref name="Abrahamsson35" /> In 1900, the association studied the possibility of creating a long [[hiking]] trail crossing the Lapland mountains, between [[Abisko]] and Kvikkjokk.<ref name="Abrahamsson36">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=36}}</ref> The initial proposal was for a marked trail that passed through the park, a boat crossing of the Rapaselet and a [[mountain hut]] beside the river.<ref name="Abrahamsson37" /><ref name="Abrahamsson36" /> The project was abandoned and the STF concentrated mostly on Kebnekaise and [[Sylan]].<ref name="Abrahamsson37" /> The trail (Kungsleden) was built, but only coming close to the park in the southeast corner of it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vandringleder|url=http://kvikkjokkfjallstation.se/Kvikkjokk_Fjallstation/Vandringstips|website=www.kvikkjokkfjallstation.se|publisher=Kvikkjokks fjällstation|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref>
In 1946, [[Dag Hammarskjöld]] popularised the expression "''vår sista stora vildmark''" ("our last great wilderness").<ref name="Abrahamsson39" /> Dag Hammarskjöld advocated a growing tourism in the park, that took care not to damage the environment.<ref name="Abrahamsson39" /> Edvin Nilsson's 1970 book on the park strengthened its reputation, increasing the number of tourists from two or three hundred in the 1960s, to 2,000 in 1971.<ref name="Abrahamsson40" /> This sudden success caused several problems such as the temporary overcrowding on certain trails in the Rapa Valley, which were not designed to accommodate so many visitors.<ref name="Abrahamsson40">{{harvnb|Abrahamsson|1993|p=40}}</ref>
== Management and regulation ==
=== The general case === [[File:Sarek reindeers.jpg|thumb|A herd of reindeer grazing in the park.]] As for the majority of the Swedish national parks, the management and administration of the park is divided between the Environmental Protection Agency of Sweden and the [[County administrative boards of Sweden|County administrative board]].<ref name=loi>{{cite web|url=http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/lag/19870938.htm|work=Notisum|title=Nationalparksförordning (1987:938)|accessdate=17 September 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> The Environmental Protection Agency is in charge of proposing new national parks in consultation with the county and [[Municipalities of Sweden|municipality]] council. The establishing of each new park requires a decision from the Riksdag.<ref name=loi /> After that, the land is bought by the government through the intermediary of the Environmental Protection Agency.<ref name=loi /> The rest of the park's management is done by the county council. In Sarek's case, this is the [[Norrbotten County]] council.
The park rules are relatively strict, to preserve the park in its near-pristine condition. Fishing, hunting, picking flowers and any other activity that could damage the wildlife are all forbidden, except for picking berries and [[edible mushroom]]s.<ref name=regles>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturvardsverket.se/upload/04_arbete_med_naturvard/världsarv/1/Forslag_nyaforeskrifter_sakagarremiss.pdf|work=Naturvårdsverket|title=Förslag till nya föreskrifter för nationalparkerna/suoddjimpárkajda Sarek Stora Sjöfallet/Stuor Muorkke Muddus/Muttos Padjelanta/ Badjelánnda och luonndoreserváhtajda/naturreservaten Sjávnja/Sjaunja Stubbá/Stubba|accessdate=2 November 2011|language=Swedish}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Similarly, no motorised vehicles are allowed in the park.<ref name=regles />
=== The Sami exception === [[File:Padjelanta Sarek Stora Sjöfallet National Park reindeer herding map-fr.svg|thumb|Map of reindeer altitudes in the three neighbouring parks.]] There are several exceptions in the laws about management and regulation of the national parks regarding the Sami. In 1977, the Sami people were recognised by Sweden as an [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] and a [[minority group]], which implies that the people and their way of life are protected by law.<ref name=samiloi>{{cite web|url=http://www.sametinget.se/4802|work=Sametinget|title=Diskriminering av samer – samers rättigheter ur ett diskrimineringsperspektiv|accessdate=2 November 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> This grants the Sami the right to farm reindeer in the park.<ref name=regles /> The park is situated on territory belonging to the [[Siida|Sami communities]] of Sirkas, Jåhkågaskka and Tuorpons, the Sami who are members of these communities are also allowed to pasture their reindeer in the park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lansstyrelsen.se/norrbotten/Sv/djur-och-natur/skyddad-natur/nationalparker/sarek/Pages/default.aspx|work=Länsstyrelsen i Norrbotten|title=Sarek|accessdate=2 October 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref> In carrying out these activities, the Sami have the right to use motorised vehicles such as snowmobiles or helicopters.<ref name=regles />
These rights are sometimes conflicting with the protection of wildlife. An example of this is when carnivores attack the Sami reindeer. Such an incident occurred in 2007, when an unregistered wolf, a protected and endangered species in Sweden, wandered into an area in Tjåmotis ({{convert|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} southeast of the Rapa Valley) where reindeer were grazing. The wolf was captured, [[Telemetry|radio-collared]] and [[Genetic testing|DNA tested]]. It was kept under surveillance and attempts were made to scare it away, but after it had killed several reindeer and disrupted the herd, a decision was made to shoot it. The decision and the killing were made collectively by the Norrbotten County Administrative Board, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Sami in accordance with the national [[nuisance wildlife management]] act.<ref>{{cite web|title=Varg skjuten i Jokkmokk|trans-title=Wolf shot in Jokkmokk|url=http://www.nsd.se/nyheter/varg-skjuten-i-jokkmokk-3536414.aspx|website=www.nsd.se|publisher=[[Norrländska Socialdemokraten]]|date=9 February 2007|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Vargjakt i Norrbotten|trans-title=Wolf hunt in Norrbotten|url=http://www.jaktojagare.se/kategorier/notiser/vargjakt-i-norrbotten/|website=www.jaktojagare.se|publisher=Jägarnas Riksförbund|date=7 February 2007|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
There is also an ongoing debate about the damages caused by snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles in the parks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Edin|first=Ronny|title=Terrängkörning i svenska fjällvärlden|trans-title=Terrain vehicles in the Swedish mountain area|url=http://www.lansstyrelsen.se/norrbotten/SiteCollectionDocuments/Sv/publikationer/djur%20och%20natur/Motortrafik%20i%20Naturen/13_2007_Terrangkorning_sv_fjallvarlden.pdf|website=www.lansstyrelsen.se|publisher=Norrbotten County Administrative Board|date=2007|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> The snowmobiles have become increasingly popular and numerous, while global warming has made the terrain more vulnerable to the vehicles. Joyrides by visitors outside the marked trails have become a problem, especially for the Sami, since they claim that the disruptions made by snowmobiles may cause the pregnant female reindeer to drop their calves prematurely.<ref>{{cite web|title=Skoterförbud i fjället|trans-title=Ban on snowmobiles in the mountains|url=http://www.vk.se/538067/skoterforbud-i-fjallet?mobil|website=www.vk.se|publisher=[[Västerbottens-Kuriren]]|date=11 April 2011|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lindgren|first1=Maria|last2=Callne|first2=Lena|title=Dålig respekt för skoterförbud i fjällen|trans-title=Prohibition for snowmobiles not respected|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=98&artikel=5839433|website=www.sverigesradio.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|date=16 April 2014|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Swedish Snowmobile Regulations|url=http://www.snoskoterradet.se/english/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202210617/http://www.snoskoterradet.se/english/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 February 2009|website=www.snoskoterradet.se|publisher=National Council on Snowmobiles|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
== In popular culture == The park was the main setting of the 2017 film [[The Ritual (2017 film)|The Ritual]].

The '''Seneschal of Gascony''' was an officer carrying out and managing the domestic affairs of the lord of the [[Duchy of Gascony]]. During the course of the twelfth century, the [[seneschal|seneschalship]], also became an office of military command. After 1360, the officer was the '''Seneschal of Aquitaine'''.<ref name=GRP>[http://www.gasconrolls.org/en/research-tools/duchy-office-holders/ "Principal Office Holders in the Duchy"] and [http://www.gasconrolls.org/en/research-tools/duchy-office-holders/seneschals-of-gascony-of-aquitaine-after-1360-1273-1453/ "Seneschals of Gascony, of Aquitaine after 1360 (1273–1453)"], ''The Gascon Rolls Project (1317–1468)''.</ref> There was an office above the seneschalcy, the [[Lieutenant of the Duchy of Aquitaine|Lieutenancy of the Duchy of Aquitaine]], but it was filled only intermittently (in times of emergency).
The seneschal managed the household, coordinating between the receivers of various landholdings and the chamber, treasury, and the chancellory or chapel. The seneschals of Gascony, like those appointed in [[Seneschal of Normandy|Normandy]], [[Seneschal of Poitou|Poitou]], and [[Seneschal of Anjou|Anjou]] had custody of demesne fortresses, the regional treasuries, and presidency of the highest court of regional custom. Detailed records of the Gascon Exchequers during the reign of [[Henry III of England]] indicate that there most likely was a functioning exchequer.

{{Refimprove|date=November 2009}} The '''Surface Transportation Assistance Act''' of 1982 was a comprehensive transportation funding and policy act of the [[United States Federal Government]], {{USStat|96|2097}}. The legislation was championed by the [[Reagan administration]] to address concerns about the surface transportation infrastructure (highways and bridges). The Act contained Title V, known as the [[Highway Revenue Act of 1982]], which added five cents to the per gallon gas tax (the first such increase since 1961), of which four cents was dedicated to restore interstate highways and bridges, and one cent for public transit. The Act also set a goal of 10 percent for participation of disadvantaged business enterprises in federal-aid projects.
== Section 165: "Buy America" Act == {{main|Buy America Act}}
Section 165 ({{usc-clause|49|5323|j}}), called the "Buy America" provision or [[Buy America Act]]—not to be confused with the 1933-enacted [[Buy American Act]]—applies to [[public transport|mass-transit]]-related procurements.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Buy American and Buy America Acts|date=May 22, 2009|publisher=[[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade]], [[Canada]]|url=http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/sell2usgov-vendreaugouvusa/procurement-marches/buyamerica.aspx?lang=eng|accessdate=2009-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100513230601/http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/sell2usgov-vendreaugouvusa/procurement-marches/buyamerica.aspx?lang=eng|archivedate=May 13, 2010|df=}}</ref> It established requirements intended to give preference to the use of domestically produced materials on any procurements funded at least in part by federal funds.<ref>{{cite web|title=Buy America Requirements (amendment of)|date=June 19, 1986|publisher=[[Federal Transit Administration]]|url=http://www.fta.dot.gov/printer_friendly/leg_reg_564.html|accessdate=2009-11-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091204025952/http://www.fta.dot.gov/printer_friendly/leg_reg_564.html|archivedate=December 4, 2009|df=}}</ref> Implementation of the requirements is regulated by the [[Federal Transit Administration]].
== Section 405 == Effective in 1983, Section 405 ({{USC|49|31105}}) was enacted to encourage employee reporting of noncompliance with safety regulations governing commercial motor vehicles. Congress recognized that employees in the transportation industry are often best able to detect safety violations and yet, because they may be threatened with discharge for cooperating with enforcement agencies, they need express protection against retaliation for reporting these violations. See, e. g., 128 Cong. Rec. 32698 (1982) (remarks of Sen. Percy); id., at 32509–32510 (remarks of Sen. Danforth). Section 405 protects employee "[[whistle-blowers]]" by forbidding discharge, discipline, or other forms of discrimination by the employer in response to an employee's complaining about or refusing to operate motor vehicles that do not meet the applicable safety standards.
Congress also recognized that the employee's protection against having to choose between operating an unsafe vehicle and losing his job would lack practical effectiveness if the [481 U.S. 252, 259] employee could not be reinstated pending complete review. The longer a discharged employee remains unemployed, the more devastating are the consequences to his personal financial condition and prospects for reemployment. Ensuring the eventual recovery of backpay may not alone provide sufficient protection to encourage reports of safety violations. Accordingly, 405 incorporates additional protections, authorizing temporary reinstatement based on a preliminary finding of reasonable cause to believe that the employee has suffered a retaliatory discharge. The statute reflects a careful balancing of the relative interests of the Government, employee, and employer. It evidences a legislative determination that the preliminary investigation and finding of reasonable cause by the Secretary, if followed "expeditiously" by a hearing on the record at the employer's request, provide effective protection to the employee and ensure fair consideration of the employer's interest in making unimpaired hiring decisions.
Truck drivers who believe they have suffered retaliation for reporting violations, refusing to commit violations, or participating in proceedings, can seek relief from the U.S. Department of Labor. Under STAA, truck drivers who believe they have suffered an adverse employment action (such as discharge, demotion, discipline, or denial of advancement), have 180 days to file a simple written complaint with [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA). The complaint can be postmarked or faxed to meet the deadline. If OSHA determines that a violation did occur, it can issue a preliminary order requiring reinstatement during further proceedings. Both sides will have an opportunity to present their evidence in a recorded hearing before an administrative law judge (ALJ). The ALJ's decision is reviewed by the Administrative Review Board, and parties can appeal to federal courts of appeals.
In 1987, the U.S. [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] ruled in ''Brock v. Roadway Express, Inc.'', 481 U.S. 252, that due process requires that employers receive prereinstatement notice of the employee's allegations, notice of the substance of the relevant supporting evidence, an opportunity to submit a written response, and an opportunity to meet with the investigator and present statements from rebuttal witnesses. These procedures provide a reliable initial check against mistaken decisions
== Sections 411–412: National Truck Network == {{main|National Network}}
Sections 411 and 412 ({{USC|49|31111|31114}}) first authorized the establishment a national network of highways designated for use by large trucks. On these highways, federal width and length limits apply. The National Network includes almost all of the Interstate Highway System and other, specified non-Interstate highways. Section 412 also specifically prohibits any state from denying reasonable access to the National Network. Provisions in the [[Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991]] further defined the National Network.
Trucks that are within the width and length limits specified in the Act are now referred to as "STAA trucks".<ref>http://www.dot.ca.gov/dist1/d1projects/staa.htm</ref>

A '''telesync''' ('''TS''')<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.afterdawn.com/glossary/term.cfm/telesync |title=Glossary for film piracy terms |author=afterdawn.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204122737/http://www.afterdawn.com/glossary/term.cfm/telesync |archivedate=2012-02-04 |df= }}</ref> is a [[bootleg recording]] of a [[film]] recorded in a [[movie theater]], often (although not always) filmed using a professional camera on a tripod in the projection booth. The audio of a TS is captured with a direct connection to the sound source (often an [[FM broadcasting|FM]] [[microbroadcast]] provided for the hearing-impaired, or from a [[drive-in theater]]). Sometimes the bootlegger will tape or conceal wireless microphones close to the speakers for better sound quality. A TS can be considered a higher quality type of [[Cam (bootleg)|cam]], that has the potential of better-quality audio and video.<ref>Craig2005 {{cite book |last1=Craig |first1=Paul |last2=Ron |first2=Mark |editor1-first=Mark |editor1-last=Burnett |others=Publisher: Andrew Williams, Page Layout and Art: Patricia Lupien, Acquisitions Editor: Jaime Quigley, Copy Editor: Judy Eby, Technical Editor: Mark Burnett, Indexer: Nara Wood, Cover Designer: Michael Kavish |title=Software Piracy Exposed - Secrets from the Dark Side Revealed |date=April 2005 |publisher= Syngress Publishing |location=United States of America |isbn=1-932266-98-4 |doi=10.1016/B978-193226698-6/50033-7 |pages=162–165 |chapter=Chapter 8: The Piracy Scene |quote=A telesync is a film recorded on a professional camera (often a digital beta-cam).The cameras are placed on steady tripods and the films are recorded in an empty cinema from the main projection booth. The sound is often recorded straight from the mixing board, giving the telesync a high quality of sound. Some releases even include surround sound in Audio Compression 3 ([[Dolby AC-3|AC3]]) format. Telesyncs are the most common of early releases, often being the first release [[Topsite (warez)|a movie site]] accepts. Telesync movies are easier to watch than their [[Cam (bootleg)|CAM]] counterparts, although the picture quality is usually slightly washed out and the contrast is often out of balance. Telesyncs are commonly traded on movie sites. They are the lowest quality allowed, but are still popular with many file traders. |laysummary=http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/bookdescription.cws_home/705731/description}}</ref>
The true definition of telesync would include the film being synchronized to the camera's own [[frame rate]] and shutter timing as done by television companies when preparing celluloid film for broadcast. A bootleg TS rarely, if ever, uses this form of synchronisation which can lead to additional temporal [[aliasing]].
As technology gets better, the quality of telesyncs also improves, although even the best telesyncs are [[lossy]] and will be inferior in quality to direct rips from [[Blu-ray]], [[DVD]] or digital transfers from the film itself (see [[telecine (piracy)|telecine]]). Some [[Warez group|release groups]] use [[high-definition video]] cameras to get the clearest picture possible.<ref name="nocopy">{{cite book |last1=Krömer |first1=Jan |last2=Sen |first2=Evrim |title=No copy: die Welt der digitalen Raubkopie |trans-title=No copy: the world of digital piracy |url=http://www.no-copy.org/kapitelinhalt.html |year=2007 |origyear=2006 |publisher=Tropical Publisher |location=Germany |language=German |isbn=3-932170-82-2|pages=110–111 |chapter=Chapter 3: All You Can Eat |chapterurl=https://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.no-copy.org%2Faus-dem-vorfuehrraum.html&sl=de&tl=en }}</ref> When an unlicensed copy of a film exists even before its official publication, it is often because a telesync version could be easily produced.<ref name="Kwok2004">{{cite journal|last1=Kwok|first1=Sai Ho|title=File sharing activities over BT Networks|journal=Computers in Entertainment|volume=2|issue=2|year=2004|pages=11|issn=1544-3574|doi=10.1145/1008213.1008232|quote=Pirated movies exist even before their official release since the Telesync (TS) version of movies shot in the cinema can be easily produced.}}</ref>
In the German [[warez scene]] additional tags for the audio source can be added to a telesync release. These are '''LD''' (line dubbed) for when the audio track of an unlicensed copy has been ripped from the line out connection of a projector or '''MD''' (mic dubbed) when a microphone is used for the recording. These tags are not used exclusively on cam releases though.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scenelingo.wordpress.com/2013/01/28/what-does-ld-and-md-mean/ |title=What does "LD" and "MD" mean? |date=2013-01-28}}</ref><!-- http://forum.chip.de/webserver-webhosting-clouds/line-dubbed-eigentlich-genau-481475.html *MIC.DUBBED* Ein Release wird mit einer deutschen Tonspur versehen, die per Micro im Kino aufgenommen wurde (schlechte Tonqualität - klingt oft sehr raumhaft).
*LINE.DUBBED* Ein Release wird mit einer deutschen Tonspur versehen, die über den "Line"-Ausgang von einer externen Quelle im Kino aufgenommen wurde (sehr gute Qualität). -->

[[Walter Huston]]
[[James Craig (actor)|James Craig]]
